awd_titl_txt: PRFB FY 2021: Disentangling a Genetic Paradox: Leveraging European Green Crabs to Examine Genomic and Plastic Contributions to Thermal Tolerance
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2022, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. European green crabs (Carcinus maenas) are one of the world’s most successful marine invasive species, due in part to their ability to thrive across a range of temperatures. On the North American West Coast, invasive green crabs negatively impact species important for commercial shellfish production and tribal food sovereignty through competition with native crabs, predation of juvenile shellfish, and destruction of nursery eelgrass beds. In order to accurately predict and prevent further spread and damages, it is important to understand the factors that help this species tolerate temperature changes. This work will uncover how genetic and environmental factors contribute to an individual crab’s temperature tolerance. The fellow will expand on previous justice, diversity, equity, and inclusion work by developing lessons about genetics and marine invasions for under-resourced schools in the Greater Boston area. 

West Coast C. maenas populations are characterized by substantially lower genetic diversity than in their native range. Recent discovery of a supergene (block of genes inherited together) with amino acid-changing mutations strongly associated with thermal tolerance suggests a genetic basis for C. maenas thermotolerance at a population level. While population-level differences in thermal performance are important, they can obscure the individual variation in phenotypically plastic traits that influences thermotolerance. The fellow will pair whole-animal thermal physiology, transcriptomics, and metabolomics in adult C. maenas to disentangle thermal response variation associated with acclimatory plasticity and adaptive evolution. By leveraging the mechanistic understanding provided by high-throughput sequencing technologies such as untargeted transcriptomics and metabolomics, the fellow will elucidate impacts of temperature on molecular physiology that may not be easily observed by whole-organism response metrics alone. Molecular reprogramming identified by these methods will demonstrate how individual-level thermotolerance contributes to population stress responses. This research will quantify individual thermal tolerance variation and create a framework for dissecting the mechanistic underpinnings of plasticity-adaptation interactions. The methods can be applied to other systems, and will expand the fellow’s research breadth. The fellow will providing paid research opportunities for undergraduate students from historically excluded groups in ocean sciences, thus training students in ecophysiology and molecular biology while also developing mentorship skills necessary for the fellow to be a successful professor.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
European green crabs (Carcinus maenas) are one of the world’s most successful marine invasive species. In North America, green crabs have extensive ecological and economic impacts. For example, green crabs can damage eelgrass beds that are important habitats for juvenile fish like herring. They are also voracious predators: they consume shellfish seed, which negatively impacts commercial shellfish production and food resources. They are successful at surviving and spreading in North America in part because they can withstand a wide range of temperatures. Iit is important to understand the factors that shape green crab temperature tolerance in order to accurately predict and prevent further spread and damages. Existing work provides insight into how populations of green crabs may respond to different temperatures. However, populations are made up of individual crabs. These individual crabs can have slightly different thermal tolerances than the whole population. Broader temperature tolerance in a few crabs can impact overall spread of this species. This project sought to uncover how specific genetic and environmental factors could impact temperature tolerance in an individual crab. This project develops a broad framework that can be applied to studying how other marine organisms respond to changes in their environment.

This project used several experiments to understand the various factors that affect individual crab temperature tolerance in multiple green crab populations. After exposing crabs from Massachusetts to different temperatures for one month, this project found that crabs in cold waters (5ºC) were able to adjust to these conditions: crabs at 5ºC initially moved slowly, but over the course of the experiment they slowly sped up their movements. Their counterparts in warm waters (30ºC) were unable to adjust to their conditions: these crabs had much higher mortality. These whole animal changes were facilitated by internal changes to energy production and usage. A different set of experiments sought to understand how a specific cluster of genes related to population-level temperature tolerance impacted individual crab temperature tolerance. Variation in this genetic cluster was associated with differences in crab movement in crabs from Massachusetts exposed to very cold (1.5ºC) temperatures. However, variation in this genetic cluster was not associated with crab movement for crabs exposed to very cold (1.5ºC), cold (5ºC), or warm (25ºC) temperatures. Interestingly, genetic variation was marginally associated with oxygen consumption in Washington crabs. Taken together, this information suggests that there are differences in crab temperature tolerance between populations and within populations. This project shows the importance of measuring temperature tolerance at different levels (populations, individuals, within-individuals) to gain a full understanding of how animals respond to changes in their environment. The framework for understanding the mechanisms that shape environmental tolerance developed by this project can be applied to other systems.

This project contributed to training the future science, technology, engineering, and mathematics workforce through individualized mentorship of seven undergraduate students by the postdoctoral fellow. For the majority of these students, working on aspects of this project was their first formalized research experience. The fellow served as a primary mentor for these students, training them in various scientific techniques used over the course of this project. The fellow also worked with each student to individually design and execute independent research projects. Two of these undergraduates presented their research at international conferences, and one student won an award for their work. One student has also used this work as part of their senior thesis. Additionally, the mentorship opportunities provided by this project allowed the fellow to practice skills necessary for their position as an incoming faculty member at an undergraduate-focused institution.

The data from this project are actively being analyzed. Preliminary data has been presented at four international conferences, as well as in six invited seminars at universities across the United States. We anticipate publishing these data in three scientific publications: two will be published in 2025, and the third in 2026. One of these publications will also include results from the undergraduate intern projects. The physiology and molecular data will be available for this project by the end of 2025.
